metadata.description: Stage 1 phonemes with ALL possible grapheme spellings from comprehensive list

articulation_data.development_notes: One of the earliest sounds acquired. Should be mastered by age 3.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Lips together, vocal cords on. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Use mirror work to show lip closure. Easy sound for modeling.
articulation_data.student_tips: Put your lips together and hum. Feel the vibration.

introduction_phase.mastery_criteria: 90% accuracy in isolation and CVC words

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Double practice time with multisensory supports

advanced_learners.acceleration: Move to blends and advanced patterns

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Sam has a mat. I am Sam.
weekly_data_override.tips: Use mirror work. Show lip closure clearly.

articulation_data.development_notes: Complex fricative requiring precise tongue placement. Lisps are common until age 6.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue near roof of mouth, air flows quietly. üó£Ô∏è Unvoiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Use feather or tissue to show airflow. Common to have lisps initially.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make the snake sound. Feel the air on your hand.

introduction_phase.mastery_criteria: 90% accuracy in isolation and CVC words

formative_assessments.criterion: Identifies /s/ in initial, medial, final positions

summative_assessment.transfer: Uses /s/ knowledge in new words and blends

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Focus on tongue placement with visual/tactile cues

cultural_considerations: Some languages have different sibilant systems

weekly_data_override.assessment: Daily quick check: /s/ sound production without lisp
weekly_data_override.tips: Use feather test for airflow. Watch for lisps.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short vowel, typically early developing. Foundation for vowel system.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth open, tongue low and forward. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Use exaggerated mouth opening. Contrast with other vowels.
articulation_data.student_tips: Open your mouth wide like at the doctor. Say 'ahh'.

cultural_considerations: Some languages don't distinguish vowel length

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: I am at the mat. Sam is mad.
weekly_data_override.tips: Emphasize wide mouth opening. Use mirror work.

articulation_data.development_notes: Voiceless alveolar stop. May show some variability until age 4.
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue tip placement. Practice stop and release.
articulation_data.student_tips: Tap your tongue behind your top teeth.

formative_assessments.criterion: Identifies /t/ in initial and final positions

cultural_considerations: May aspirate differently in some languages

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The mat is at the top. Sam sat.
weekly_data_override.tips: Practice tongue tapping. Show stop and release.

content_generation_meta.context_sentences: Include both initial and final positions

articulation_data.development_notes: Early developing nasal sound. Should be consistent by age 3.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue tip behind teeth, air through nose. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.student_tips: Put your tongue tip up, air comes out your nose.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The man can nap. I am not mad.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show nasal airflow with mirror or tissue.

articulation_data.development_notes: Early bilabial stop. Usually acquired with /b/ and /m/.
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show lip closure and release. No voice.
articulation_data.student_tips: Press your lips together, then pop them open.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Pat has a map. I can tap the pan.
weekly_data_override.tips: Emphasize lip closure and release. Practice without voice.

content_generation_meta.context_sentences: Include both initial and final positions

articulation_data.development_notes: Short i vowel. Usually well-established by age 3.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth slightly open, lips relaxed, tongue high-mid. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue position higher than /a/. Spread lips slightly.
articulation_data.student_tips: Say 'ih' with your mouth almost closed.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: I sit in the pit. Pat has the tip.
weekly_data_override.tips: Contrast with /a/. Show tongue position differences.

articulation_data.development_notes: Voiced alveolar stop. Should be consistent by age 4.
articulation_data.student_tips: Tap your tongue and turn on your voice.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Dad is mad. I am sad.

articulation_data.development_notes: Fricative that develops gradually. Normal variation until age 6.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Teeth on lip, air flows. üó£Ô∏è Unvoiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show teeth on lip contact. Demonstrate airflow.
articulation_data.student_tips: Bite your bottom lip gently, blow air out.

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Extended fricative work with visual cues

cultural_considerations: /f/ may not exist in all languages

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The fat man has a fan. If I can fit.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show teeth on lip. Use feather for airflow.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short o vowel. May vary with dialect.
articulation_data.student_tips: Make your lips round like you're surprised.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The pot is on top. I can mop the dot.
weekly_data_override.tips: Emphasize lip rounding. Use mirror work.

articulation_data.development_notes: Liquid sound requiring complex tongue movement. May vary by position in word.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Tongue touches behind top teeth. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show tongue tip contact. Demonstrate lateral airflow.
articulation_data.student_tips: Touch your tongue tip behind your teeth.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: I sit on dad's lap. The lamp is lit.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show tongue tip contact. Practice sustained /l/.

articulation_data.development_notes: Simple fricative, usually early developing. May be omitted in connected speech.
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show gentle airflow. Like fogging a mirror.
articulation_data.student_tips: Breathe out gently like you're warming your hands.

struggling_learners.additional_practice: Extended airflow work with visual cues

cultural_considerations: /h/ may be omitted in some languages

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The hat is hot. I hit the ham.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show gentle airflow. Use mirror fogging.

articulation_data.development_notes: Early developing voiced stop. Typically emerges with /p/.
articulation_data.student_tips: Press your lips together, turn on your voice, then pop them open.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The bat is bad. I can bat the ball.

decodable_sentences: The pet is in the pen.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short e vowel. May show variation until age 4.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth slightly open, tongue mid-high. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show position between /a/ and /i/. Mid vowel.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: Let me pet the dog. I bet it is soft.
weekly_data_override.tips: Show vowel ladder position. Practice vowel substitution.

decodable_sentences: Put the mud in the hut.

articulation_data.development_notes: Short u vowel. Foundation for back vowel development.
articulation_data.articulation_cues: üëÑ Mouth relaxed, tongue mid-low central. üó£Ô∏è Voiced
articulation_data.teacher_guidance: Show relaxed mouth position. Often confused with /o/.

weekly_data_override.decodable_text: The sun is fun. Put mud in the hut.
weekly_data_override.tips: Complete vowel system. Practice all five vowels.
